<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_flush:
```c
static int lfs_file_flush(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_READING) {
        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &file->cache);
        }
        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_READING;
    }

#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_WRITING) {
        lfs_off_t pos = file->pos;

        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            // copy over anything after current branch
            lfs_file_t orig = {
                .ctz.head = file->ctz.head,
                .ctz.size = file->ctz.size,
                .flags = LFS_O_RDONLY,
                .pos = file->pos,
                .cache = lfs->rcache,
            };
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &lfs->rcache);

            while (file->pos < file->ctz.size) {
                // copy over a byte at a time, leave it up to caching
                // to make this efficient
                uint8_t data;
                lfs_ssize_t res = lfs_file_flushedread(lfs, &orig, &data, 1);
                if (res < 0) {
                    return res;
                }

                res = lfs_file_flushedwrite(lfs, file, &data, 1);
                if (res < 0) {
                    return res;
                }

                // keep our reference to the rcache in sync
                if (lfs->rcache.block != LFS_BLOCK_NULL) {
                    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &orig.cache);
                    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, &lfs->rcache);
                }
            }

            // write out what we have
            while (true) {
                int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, &file->cache, &lfs->rcache, true);
                if (err) {
                    if (err == LFS_ERR_CORRUPT) {
                        goto relocate;
                    }
                    return err;
                }

                break;

relocate:
                LFS_DEBUG("Bad block at 0x%"PRIx32, file->block);
                err = lfs_file_relocate(lfs, file);
                if (err) {
                    return err;
                }
            }
        } else {
            file->pos = lfs_max(file->pos, file->ctz.size);
        }

        // actual file updates
        file->ctz.head = file->block;
        file->ctz.size = file->pos;
        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_WRITING;
        file->flags |= LFS_F_DIRTY;

        file->pos = pos;
    }
#endif

    return 0;
}
```

explanation:
I found no usages of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided function. The constructs present and why they are not flagged:

- Designated initializers (e.g. lfs_file_t orig = { .ctz.head = ..., .ctz.size = ... };) are standard C (C99/C11) and are not a compiler extension.
- Single-line // comments and the use of true are standard (C99/stdbool.h) rather than compiler extensions.
- String literal concatenation with format macros ("0x%"PRIx32) and use of standard integer types (uint8_t, uint16_t) are standard C facilities.
- goto, labels, while(true), casts like (lfs_block_t)-1, and struct initializers are standard C constructs.

No occurrences of known compiler-specific extensions were found (for example: __attribute__, __asm, __declspec, statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, labels-as-values, or other vendor-specific keywords). Therefore there are no code fragments that need to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions) in this snippet.
